title: Introduction

title: Predicting Billboard Ranks with Machine Learning : An Intro
content:
Before we get into machine learning, we need to set up the foundation: the Billboard Hot 100 dataset. This dataset, sourced from Kaggle, contains detailed weekly chart information going back decades.

ğŸ” Whatâ€™s in the Dataset?

The dataset includes key columns such as:

date â†’ The Billboard chart week.

rank â†’ The current weekâ€™s Hot 100 position (our target variable).

song â†’ Track title.

artist â†’ Performer(s).

last-week â†’ Position in the previous week.

peak-rank â†’ The highest position the song has ever reached.

weeks-on-board â†’ How many weeks the song has stayed on the Hot 100.

These features make it possible to spot trendsâ€”like whether a song is rising, falling, or stable.

ğŸ§¹ Preprocessing Steps

Cleaning Missing Values

Some entries donâ€™t have complete rank history (especially when a song first enters the chart). These were handled carefully so the model doesnâ€™t misinterpret them.

Column Standardization

Renamed and reformatted columns for consistency (e.g., replacing hyphens with underscores).

Feature Engineering

Focused on predictive features like last_week, peak_rank, and weeks_on_board.

Converted categorical text columns (like artist) into usable numeric form where necessary.

Normalization

Scaled numeric values so that features like â€œweeks on boardâ€ and â€œrankâ€ are comparable to each other.

ğŸ’¡ Why This Step Matters

A machine learning model canâ€™t make sense of raw Billboard data without preparation. By cleaning and structuring the dataset, we give the model the chance to actually learn patternsâ€”like why some songs shoot to #1 while others slowly fade.

title: Predicting Billboard Ranks with Machine Learning : Preparing Dataset
content:
Before any machine learning magic can happen, the most important step is understanding and cleaning the data. A model is only as good as the data it learns fromâ€”so this stage sets the foundation for everything else.

ğŸ” The Dataset

For this project, I used a structured dataset (sourced from Kaggle)  that contains features related to individual performance. In this case Each row represents a person, and each column describes something about themâ€”for example:

Exam or test scores

Participation/attendance metrics

Performance in certain activities

Final outcome (rank/position)

This rank column is what we want to predict.

ğŸ§¹ Preprocessing Steps

Raw data almost always needs some work before itâ€™s ready for machine learning. Hereâ€™s what I did:

Cleaning Missing Values

Some rows had incomplete information. I either filled them with reasonable estimates (like averages) or removed them if too much data was missing.

Renaming and Standardizing Columns

To avoid confusion later, I made sure column names were consistent and easy to read.

Feature Selection

Not every column in the dataset helps with prediction. I selected the most relevant features that likely influence rank.

Encoding and Normalization

If there were any categorical variables (like â€œyes/noâ€ fields), I converted them into numbers so the model could understand them.

I also scaled numerical values so that features with large ranges didnâ€™t overpower smaller ones.

ğŸ’¡ Why This Matters

Preprocessing might feel less exciting than model training, but itâ€™s absolutely critical. If the data is messy or poorly prepared, even the best machine learning model will struggle. By making the dataset clean and structured, we give the model the best chance to learn meaningful patterns.

title: Predicting Billboard Ranks : Exploring the Billboard Hot 100 Dataset (EDA)
content:
Now that weâ€™ve cleaned up the dataset, itâ€™s time to ask:
ğŸ‘‰ What story does the data tell us about Billboard hits?

Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) is where we look at trends, patterns, and relationships in the data before jumping into model training. For the Billboard Hot 100, this step helps us understand what influences a songâ€™s chart performance.

Key Insights from the Data
1. Distribution of Ranks

Most songs in the dataset spend a lot of their lifetime in the lower part of the Hot 100 (50â€“100 range). Very few reach the coveted Top 10, and even fewer manage to hit #1.
This makes sense: the higher the rank, the tougher the competition.

2. Weeks on Board vs. Rank

Songs that stick around for 20+ weeks usually had strong peak positions (Top 20 or higher).

Many songs debut high but then drop quickly if they donâ€™t sustain streams, airplay, or buzz.

ğŸ‘‰ Longevity is just as important as peak rank.

3. Last Weekâ€™s Rank as a Predictor

If a song was #5 last week, chances are it will stay close to that rank next week. The dataset shows strong correlation between last_week and rank.
This suggests chart movement is more gradual than random.

4. Peak Rank as a Ceiling

A songâ€™s peak rank acts like a ceilingâ€”it rarely jumps higher than that after the first few weeks. Once a track peaks, it tends to stabilize or decline.

ğŸ¶ Examples from the Data

Long Runners: Some songs stay on the chart for 50+ weeks (think â€œBlinding Lightsâ€ by The Weeknd). These songs usually maintain strong middle-to-high ranks for months.

Quick Climbers: Viral hits often shoot into the Top 10 quickly, but unless theyâ€™re backed by consistent streams/airplay, they fall just as fast.

ğŸ’¡ Why EDA Matters Here

EDA tells us which features might be most useful for prediction. From this dataset, itâ€™s clear that:

last_week rank

peak_rank

weeks_on_board

â€¦are strong indicators of where a song will land next week. These insights directly guide our feature selection for the model.
